conversation.speaker: AI
conversation.text: So nice to meet you, Miguel! I'm Loora, your personal Al English tutor. Talk with me for just 5 minutes a day, and see how you become a confident English speaker! So tell me, where are you from?

conversation.speaker: student
conversation.text: Hello, Loora. Nice to meet you. My name is Miguel. I'm from Colombia, Latin America. It's a pleasure to meet you. Thank you.
conversation.loora_say_it_like_a_native: Hi Loora! I’m Miguel from Colombia. Really nice meeting you — thanks for having me!
conversation.loora_better_to_say: Hello, Loora. It's a pleasure to meet you. I'm Miguel, and I'm from Colombia, which is in South America. Thank you!

loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: Adds clarity with a full subject.

loora_grammar_corrections.correction: I'm from Colombia, in South America
loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: More specific and commonly used phrasing when talking about location.

sounds.feedback: Clear, but could be slightly smoother.
Try keeping this unstressed and short.

fragments.comment: Simple and polite greeting. Well used.
Adding 'It's' makes the sentence complete.
Clear and grammatically correct introduction.

fragments.correction_1: I'm from Colombia, in South America.
fragments.correction_2: I'm from Colombia. It's in South America.
fragments.comment: 'South America' is more precise and common in spoken English.

fragments.success_sentence: It's a pleasure to meet you.
fragments.comment: Polite and well-formed sentence.
Simple and appropriate closing.

conversation.result_sentence_1: Hello, Loora. Nice to meet you. My name is Miguel. I'm from Colombia, in South America. It's a pleasure to meet you. Thank you.
conversation.result_sentence_2: Hello, Loora. It's nice to meet you. My name is Miguel. I'm from Colombia. It's in South America. Thank you!
conversation.say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Hey Loora! I’m Miguel from Colombia. Really glad to meet you — thanks for chatting!

conversation.speaker: AI
conversation.text: It's great to meet you! Colombia has such a rich culture and beautiful landscapes—what do you love most about living there?

conversation.speaker: student
conversation.text: Well, I was born here. I don't know other countries abroad, but I like everything, I think so.
conversation.loora_say_it_like_a_native: Well, I was born here. I don't know about other countries, but I like everything here, I believe.
conversation.loora_better_to_say: Well, I was born here. I don't know about other countries abroad, but I like everything, I think.

loora_grammar_corrections.original: I don't know other countries abroad
loora_grammar_corrections.correction: I don't know about other countries abroad
loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: The verb 'know' requires 'about' when referring to general knowledge of places or things.

loora_grammar_corrections.original: I like everything, I think so
loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: 'I think so' means agreement with someone else’s idea. 'I think' is used when expressing your own opinion.

sounds.feedback: Could be clearer, try softening it.

fragments.comment: Good structure and clear meaning.

fragments.error_sentence: I don't know other countries abroad
fragments.correction_1: I don't know about other countries abroad
fragments.comment: Missing 'about' which is needed to express general knowledge.

fragments.error_sentence: I like everything, I think so
fragments.comment: 'I think so' sounds unnatural here. Use 'I think' to share your own thoughts.

conversation.result_sentence_1: Well, I was born here. I don't know about other countries abroad, but I like everything, I think.
conversation.result_sentence_2: Well, I was born here. I don't know about other countries, but I like everything here, I believe.
conversation.say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Honestly, I was born here and haven’t really seen other countries yet, but I like everything about living here!

conversation.speaker: AI
conversation.text: That's wonderful! It's great that you appreciate everything about your home. If you could visit any country someday, where would you like to go?

conversation.loora_better_to_say: Well, definitely the US, United States, because when I was a child, I saw a lot of movies about, you know, Disney World, something like that, and I have a good image of them, and one day I want to travel there.

Use the English name in English conversations.

conversation.text: No worries at all! Disney movies can be really memorable, even if we forget specific titles. Do you remember any characters or themes that stood out to you from those movies?

Say it like a native speaker
Well, I don't remember anything in particular about Disney, but I remember other movies that I really like nowadays, such as The Matrix, for example. It's a good movie; it's a science fiction action film.
conversation.loora_better_to_say: Well, I don't remember in particular about Disney, but I remember another movies that I like so much nowadays, like Matrix, for example, it's a good movie, it's like a science fiction action movie.

loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: 'Another' is singular; 'movies' is plural. Use 'other' for plural nouns.
Use 'really like' for more natural emphasis; 'so much' sounds awkward here.
Movie titles in English typically include 'The' when it's part of the name.

conversation.text: The Matrix is a fantastic choice! It really blends action and thought-provoking themes, doesn't it? What do you like most about that movie?

conversation.speaker: student
conversation.text: Well, it's so interesting because it's like a reality, well, a little exaggerating reality, but maybe in the future, maybe that happens. I don't know.
conversation.loora_say_it_like_a_native: Well, it's so interesting because it's like a reality, albeit an exaggerated one. Perhaps something like that could happen in the future; I don't know.
conversation.loora_better_to_say: Well, it's so interesting because it's like a reality, well, a little exaggerated reality, but maybe in the future, maybe that happens. I don't know.

loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: Use 'exaggerated' (adjective) to describe 'reality'; 'exaggerating' is a verb form and incorrect in this context.

fragments.comment: Good natural opening expressing opinion.

Your sentence is understandable and works for an A2 level. The idea is clear. However, native speakers would usually say 'because it feels real' instead. The phrase 'like a reality' is grammatically okay, but it's not commonly used in this context. To sound more natural, try using 'real', 'real life', or 'realistic' depending on your meaning.
'Exaggerating' is a verb; the adjective form 'exaggerated' is needed here.

fragments.success_sentence: maybe in the future, maybe that happens
fragments.comment: Repetitive but understandable. Try saying 'perhaps it could happen in the future' for smoother flow.
Good closing — natural and humble.

conversation.result_sentence_1: Well, it's so interesting because it's like a reality — a little exaggerated, but maybe in the future that could happen. I don't know.
conversation.result_sentence_2: Well, it's so interesting — like an exaggerated reality. Maybe it could happen someday, who knows?
conversation.say_it_like_a_native_speaker: It's such a cool movie because it feels kinda real — just an exaggerated version. Who knows? Maybe one day it could happen!

conversation.speaker: AI
conversation.text: That's a fascinating perspective! The idea of blending reality with technology makes it so thought-provoking. Do you enjoy other science fiction movies, or is The Matrix your favorite?

conversation.speaker: student
conversation.text: Lately I saw several movies, like romance movies. I like it as well so much. For example, recently I saw the movie called Before Sunrise. It's like a beautiful movie. I don't know if you know about that movie, Before Sunrise. It's a romance movie.
conversation.loora_say_it_like_a_native: Recently, I have seen several movies, including romance films. I enjoy them quite a bit as well. For example, I recently watched a movie called Before Sunrise. It's a beautiful film. I don't know if you're familiar with it, but Before Sunrise is a romance movie.
conversation.loora_better_to_say: Lately I saw several movies, like romance movies. I like it so much as well. For example, recently I saw the movie called Before Sunrise. It's a beautiful movie. I don't know if you know about that movie, Before Sunrise. It's a romance movie.

loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: Use present perfect with 'lately' to describe recent experience.

loora_grammar_corrections.original: I like it as well so much
loora_grammar_corrections.correction: I like them very much as well
loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: Use 'them' for plural 'movies' and adjust word order for fluency.
Remove 'like' which adds unnecessary hesitation or doubt.

loora_grammar_corrections.original: do you know about that movie
loora_grammar_corrections.correction: are you familiar with that movie
loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: More natural way to ask if someone knows a specific movie.

fragments.comment: 'Lately' typically pairs with present perfect ('have seen') rather than past simple ('saw').

error_origin.explanation: The speaker used the past simple with an adverb that usually calls for present perfect.

fragments.advice: Practice using 'have seen' or 'have watched' with adverbs like 'lately', 'recently', and 'so far'.

fragments.error_sentence: I like it as well so much
fragments.correction_1: I like them very much as well
fragments.correction_2: I also enjoy them a lot
fragments.comment: Use 'them' instead of 'it' to refer to multiple movies, and rephrase for natural tone.

error_origin.explanation: 'Movies' is plural, so the correct pronoun is 'them'.

fragments.advice: Review singular vs plural pronouns (it vs them) and placement of 'so much', 'as well', etc.
fragments.suggested_natural_alternative: I really enjoy those kinds of movies too

fragments.success_sentence: For example, recently I saw the movie called Before Sunrise.
fragments.comment: Clear sentence structure with good vocabulary for giving examples.
fragments.suggested_natural_alternative: I recently saw a movie called *Before Sunrise*

fragments.comment: Avoid 'like' here; it weakens your message unnecessarily.

error_origin.explanation: 'Like' is sometimes used as a filler word and doesn't add value here.

fragments.advice: Practice saying strong, clear opinions without extra filler: 'It’s a great movie', not 'It’s like a great movie'.

fragments.error_sentence: I don't know if you know about that movie
fragments.correction_1: I don’t know if you’re familiar with that movie
fragments.correction_2: You might know it — it's called Before Sunrise
fragments.comment: ‘Know about’ is technically correct but not as smooth in casual speech.

error_origin.explanation: Phrase is likely a literal translation from Spanish structure.

fragments.advice: Practice using 'familiar with', 'heard of', or 'seen' when talking about movies or cultural references.
fragments.suggested_natural_alternative: You might know it — it’s called Before Sunrise

conversation.say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Lately I’ve been watching romance movies too — like *Before Sunrise*. It’s such a beautiful film. Have you seen it?

conversation.text: Before Sunrise is a beautiful film! The way it captures a deep connection between two people over just one night is really special.

conversation.text: well another movie is like before before sunrise before sunrise and in that I remember that is saying that I like it for example it was when the boy tried to go to the girl that I like it and he tried to get up in the rollercoaster not not not really rollercoaster it's like part of the diversions but I don't remember the name of that attraction but it was a little dangerous because he tried to tell her that he wanted to go out with her but he tried to suicide but only joking I donʼt know if you know about that the same of the before sunrise I think
conversation.loora_say_it_like_a_native: Well, another movie is 'Before Sunrise'. In that film, I remember a scene that I really like. It's when the boy tries to approach the girl, and he attempts to get on the ride. It's not really a rollercoaster; it's part of the attractions, but I can't remember the name of that ride. It was a little dangerous because he was trying to express that he wanted to go out with her, but he jokingly pretended to commit suicide. I don't know if you're familiar with that scene from 'Before Sunrise'.
conversation.loora_better_to_say: Well, another movie is like before, before sunrise, before sunrise. In that, I remember that it is saying that I like it. For example, it was when the boy tried to go to the girl that I like, and he tried to get up in the roller coaster. Not, not, not really a roller coaster; it's like part of the diversions, but I don't remember the name of that attraction. But it was a little dangerous because he tried to tell her that he wanted to go out with her, but he tried to commit suicide, but only joking. I don't know if you know about that; the same as before sunrise, I think.

loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: In English, 'suicide' is a noun. You can't use it directly as a verb.
Repetition and confusion—only say the movie title once.
‘Diversions’ is uncommon here. ‘Attractions’ is the natural word in the context of a fair or amusement park.

fragments.comment: Repetitions and lack of structure made it hard to follow.

error_origin.explanation: The speaker repeated the title several times, possibly unsure of phrasing.

error_origin.explanation: Speaker tried to refer to the guy's intention but introduced the wrong possessive.

fragments.suggested_natural_alternative: he accomplished what he wanted with her

conversation.result_sentence_1: Yes, exactly. That scene was powerful — both funny and dangerous. The girl was scared, but he finally made her understand he wanted to go on a date. In the end, he achieved his goal.
conversation.result_sentence_2: Yes, exactly. It was such an impactful scene. The boy took a risky move that made the girl realize he wanted to be with her — it worked, and it was a bit crazy but funny too.
conversation.say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Totally! It was funny and kind of dangerous — he made her realize he wanted a date, and it actually worked. A bit crazy, but cute too!

conversation.speaker: AI
conversation.text: That scene really highlights the mix of emotions that come with falling in love! It's interesting how humor can lighten even the most intense moments.

conversation.speaker: student
conversation.text: Yeah, you're right. I agree with you.
conversation.loora_say_it_like_a_native: Yeah, totally! I agree with you.
conversation.loora_better_to_say: Yeah, you're right. I totally agree with you.

fragments.comment: Natural confirmation and agreement with the AI's statement.
Clear and polite way to show agreement.

conversation.speaker: AI
conversation.text: It's wonderful that you feel comfortable both alone and with company—it shows a great balance! It was great getting to know you today, and I look forward to our next lesson tomorrow at 00:10, where I'll share your first Daily Word!

reading.title: What is AI?
reading.summary: Artificial intelligence refers to machines that can perform tasks requiring human intelligence.
reading.reflection_prompt: How do you think AI will change jobs in the future?

conversation.speaker: AI
conversation.text: What do you think about using AI in education?

conversation.speaker: student
conversation.text: It will help teachers and students a lot.
conversation.loora_say_it_like_a_native: I think it’s a great tool to support both teachers and students.
conversation.loora_better_to_say: It’s helpful for both teachers and students.

loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: 'Support' sounds more academic in this context.

fragments.success_sentence: It will help teachers and students.
fragments.comment: Grammatically fine, and the message is clear.
The verb 'help' is fine, but 'support' or 'assist' sounds more natural in academic discussions.

error_origin.explanation: You used a common verb, but a more formal one fits the tone better.

fragments.advice: Practice replacing general verbs like 'help' with more precise ones in different settings.

practice_zone.user_response_topic: I like painting and going to the beach.

conversation.speaker: AI
conversation.text: That sounds fun! What do you usually paint?

conversation.speaker: student
conversation.text: I paint landscapes and sometimes portraits.
conversation.loora_say_it_like_a_native: I mostly paint landscapes, but I also enjoy portraits now and then.
conversation.loora_better_to_say: I usually paint landscapes and sometimes do portraits.

loora_grammar_corrections.explanation: Adds frequency for more natural flow.

sounds.feedback: Final part too quick — slow down slightly

fragments.comment: Well-constructed sentence with correct tense and vocabulary.
Good addition that adds detail to your painting activity.
Adding an adverb like 'usually' or 'mostly' makes the sentence sound more natural in conversations.

error_origin.explanation: You forgot to include a time/frequency reference that makes it sound more fluent.

fragments.advice: Practice adding frequency adverbs like 'usually', 'often', or 'sometimes' to your daily activities.
